pullRequest.body:
We define the `WellQuasiOrdered` predicate for an unbundled WQO relation, and the `WellQuasiOrderedLE` typeclass. We show some basic properties of them both.

Note that we already have the set versions [`Set.PartiallyWellOrderedOn`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/WellFoundedSet.html#Set.PartiallyWellOrderedOn) and [`Set.IsPWO`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/WellFoundedSet.html#Set.IsPWO). A future PR will redefine the set predicates in terms of the type predicates.

We call these WQOs instead of PWOs, since we're not actually requiring a partial order, but only a quasiorder (preorder).

---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [0b7fa84b17](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21008/commits/0b7fa84b17927a85009483449664e1761a9900c7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Order.WellQuasiOrder` (new file)|541|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Finite.wellQuasiOrdered`
`+ IsAntichain.finite_of_wellQuasiOrdered`
`+ WellQuasiOrdered`
`+ WellQuasiOrdered.exists_monotone_subseq`
`+ WellQuasiOrdered.prod`
`+ WellQuasiOrdered.wellFounded`
`+ WellQuasiOrderedLE`
`+ WellQuasiOrderedLE.finite_of_isAntichain`
`+ instance (priority := 100) Finite.to_wellQuasiOrderedLE [Finite α] : WellQuasiOrderedLE α`
`+ instance (priority := 100) WellQuasiOrderedLE.to_wellFoundedLT [WellQuasiOrderedLE α] :`
`+ instance [WellQuasiOrderedLE α] [Preorder β] [WellQuasiOrderedLE β] : WellQuasiOrderedLE (α × β)`
`+ wellQuasiOrderedLE_iff`
`+ wellQuasiOrderedLE_iff_wellFoundedLT`
`+ wellQuasiOrdered_iff_exists_monotone_subseq`
`+ wellQuasiOrdered_le`
`+ wellQuasiOrdered_of_isEmpty`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

```suggestion
subsequence of related elements. For a preorder, this is equivalent to having a well-founded order with no
```
since you aren't assuming transitivity in this sentence

```suggestion
/-- A typeclass for an order with a well quasi-ordered `≤` relation.
```

```suggestion
/-- A linear WQO is the same thing as a well-order. -/
```

Hmm, I'd prefer
```suggestion
/-- In a linear order, the properties of being a WQO and a well-orders are equivalent. -/
```
since the original doesn't exactly typecheck but the first suggestion can be misinterpreted as "alpha (is a linear order + wqo) iff (it is a well-order)" which isn't what the statement is saying

> the first suggestion can be misinterpreted as "alpha (is a linear order + wqo) iff (it is a well-order)" which isn't what the statement is saying

Since well-order means `LinearOrder` + `WellFoundedLT`, it actually kind of is what it's saying
Yes I agree it's what you're saying, but it's not what the theorem is saying!
I prefer Yaël's suggestion. The only difference between that statement and the theorem I prove is that the `LinearOrder` assumption isn't duplicated, which to me seems like a triviality.

pullRequest.title: feat(Order/WellQuasiOrder): `WellQuasiOrdered` predicate
